Award.AwardTitle: HNDS-I: Linked Administrative Data in Social Services

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The Linkage Initiative for Policy Evaluation and Research (LIPER) will create unique databases<br/>to support innovative social science research. The new databases will support new<br/>understandings of how households use debt and assets to weather volatility and make longterm<br/>decisions; better diagnosis of the strengths and weaknesses of the social safety net and its<br/>efficacy in supporting self-sufficiency; and new insights into the impacts of the full suite of<br/>government programs and services on a variety of outcomes, from health to housing stability to<br/>justice involvement. The databases will use administrative microdata, which is person-level data<br/>that is collected by state and local agencies in the process of providing services. Government is<br/>already collecting these data, and the project will unlock their value for understanding population<br/>needs and the efficacy of policies in meeting these needs. The LIPER databases will be<br/>particularly valuable for inclusive research involving a wide range of underrepresented groups<br/>and for understanding the complex dynamics of racial and economic equity. Access to the<br/>LIPER databases will allow investigators across a wide range of social science fields to<br/>generate accurate and actionable insights leading to more informed public policy and,<br/>ultimately, to improved individual well-being.<br/><br/>The LIPER databases will each link data from multiple agencies. Linked data of this type is<br/>increasingly important for breakthrough research. Yet in the United States, legal and technical<br/>barriers often prevent it from being used by researchers. LIPER will develop data resources,<br/>including linkages across previously separate data systems; build mechanisms and<br/>infrastructure to support wide access of researchers to the data for a range of projects, while<br/>preserving privacy and security; and provide opportunities for the next generation of social<br/>science researchers to build their research programs with LIPER data resources. It will build on<br/>existing relationships that the LIPER project researchers have with California agencies and will<br/>be housed within the California Policy Lab at UC Berkeley and UCLA, which is dedicated to<br/>using data driven insights to address urgent social problems. LIPER will be built within a secure<br/>computer infrastructure that allows remote access for approved researchers. The LIPER<br/>website will allow researchers to explore public metadata and the team will review applications<br/>for researchers to access the data in a streamlined fashion. The team will also innovate on<br/>methods for linking data without access to personally identifiable information.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
